questions.question: The Chandrasekhar limit, which determines the maximum mass of a stable white dwarf star, is approximately how many solar masses?
The War of the Triple Alliance was a devastating South American conflict fought between Paraguay and which three allied countries?
In Dante's 'Inferno,' who guides the protagonist through the nine circles of Hell?
The 'School of Athens,' a fresco depicting numerous philosophers, was painted by which High Renaissance artist?
What is the name of the enzyme that unwinds the DNA double helix during replication?
Who was the last emperor of the Byzantine Empire, dying during the Fall of Constantinople in 1453?
The philosophical principle 'Cogito, ergo sum' ('I think, therefore I am') is attributed to whom?
In computer networking, what does the acronym 'DNS' stand for?
The economic theory that advocates for minimal government intervention in the economy is known as what?
In the film '2001: A Space Odyssey,' what is the name of the malevolent artificial intelligence?
What is the SI unit of magnetic flux density?
The Islets of Langerhans, which contain the body's insulin-producing cells, are found in which organ?
The Meiji Restoration in 1868 led to the downfall of what ruling military government in Japan?
Which novel by Gabriel García Márquez tells the multi-generational story of the Buendía family in the fictional town of Macondo?
options: Love in the Time of Cholera

questions.question: 'The Persistence of Memory,' famous for its melting clocks, is a masterpiece by which Surrealist artist?
The Great Rift Valley is a major geological feature that runs primarily through which continent?
In programming, what is the time complexity of a binary search algorithm on a sorted array?
In Norse mythology, what is the name of the world tree that connects the nine worlds?
Who is the author of 'The Wealth of Nations,' a foundational text in classical economics?
The first successful expedition to the summit of Mount Everest in 1953 was led by whom?
In chemistry, what is the name of the rule stating that for a given multi-electron atom, the term with maximum multiplicity has the lowest energy?
What is the medical term for programmed cell death, a crucial process in multicellular organisms?
The 'Great Game' was a 19th-century political and diplomatic rivalry between which two empires over influence in Central Asia?
The Epic of Gilgamesh, one of the earliest surviving works of literature, originates from which ancient civilization?
Who composed the famous ballets 'The Nutcracker,' 'Swan Lake,' and 'Sleeping Beauty'?
Which of the Great Lakes is the only one that lies entirely within the United States?
Which protocol is used for sending email from a client to a server?
The 'Allegory of the Cave' is a famous concept from which philosopher's work 'The Republic'?
Which of the following is NOT a permanent member of the UN Security Council?
Who directed the classic 1954 Japanese film 'Seven Samurai'?
The Haber-Bosch process, critical for industrial agriculture, synthesizes what chemical from nitrogen and hydrogen gas?
Prions, the infectious agents responsible for diseases like Mad Cow Disease, are composed primarily of what?
The Treaty of Tordesillas (1494) divided the newly discovered lands outside Europe between which two colonial powers?
Who wrote the existentialist novel 'The Stranger' ('L'Étranger'), which begins with the line 'Mother died today.'?
The architectural style characterized by pointed arches, ribbed vaults, and flying buttresses is known as what?
What is the name of the supercontinent that existed during the late Paleozoic and early Mesozoic eras?
What was the name of the first programmable, electronic, general-purpose digital computer, completed in 1945?
In Hindu mythology, who is the preserver god and one of the principal deities of the Trimurti?
The Bretton Woods Agreement of 1944 established a system of international monetary management that pegged other currencies to what?
The term 'meme' was coined in 1976 by which evolutionary biologist in his book 'The Selfish Gene'?
In quantum mechanics, what is the term for a system where particles are linked in such a way that their fates are inseparable, regardless of distance?
What is the primary function of the sinoatrial (SA) node in the human heart?
The Taiping Rebellion, one of the deadliest conflicts in human history, occurred in which country during the mid-19th century?
What is the name of the protagonist in Fyodor Dostoevsky's 'Crime and Punishment'?
The painting 'Guernica,' a powerful anti-war statement, was created by which artist in response to a bombing during the Spanish Civil War?
The Strait of Hormuz, a critical chokepoint for global oil transport, connects the Persian Gulf with which body of water?
In cryptography, which of the following is an example of an asymmetric encryption algorithm?
Utilitarianism, the ethical theory that promotes actions maximizing happiness, was primarily developed by which two philosophers?
What is the term for a market situation where there is only one buyer for a good or service?
The Manhattan Project was a research and development undertaking during World War II that produced the first what?
Which allotrope of carbon consists of a single layer of atoms arranged in a two-dimensional honeycomb lattice?
Carl Linnaeus is famous for his work in taxonomy. What was the highest taxonomic rank in his original system?
Which battle in 1066, besides Hastings, saw an English victory over a Norwegian invasion force led by King Harald Hardrada?
The literary concept of an 'unreliable narrator' is famously exemplified by the governess in which Henry James novella?
Who composed the famous set of four violin concertos known as 'The Four Seasons'?
What is the highest mountain in North America?
The concept of 'Turing completeness' means a system of computation can theoretically solve what?
options: Any problem a Turing machine can

questions.question: In Roman mythology, who is the goddess of wisdom and strategic warfare, equivalent to the Greek Athena?
The 'separation of powers' into legislative, executive, and judicial branches was most famously articulated by which Enlightenment philosopher?
Which architect designed the famous 'Fallingwater' house in Pennsylvania?
What is the phenomenon where a spinning object moving through a fluid experiences a sideways force?
In genetics, what is the term for a specific variation of a gene?
Who was the female pharaoh of the 18th Dynasty of Egypt who reigned longer than any other woman of an indigenous Egyptian dynasty?
Which Japanese author wrote 'The Tale of Genji,' often considered the world's first novel?
The art movement characterized by a subjective perspective, distorting reality for emotional effect, is known as what?
What type of rock is formed from the cooling and solidification of magma or lava?
Who is often called the 'father of the modern computer' for his 19th-century design of the Analytical Engine?
In Greek mythology, who was the ferryman of the dead across the river Styx?
The 'invisible hand' is a metaphor used by Adam Smith to describe what?
options: Unintended social benefits of individual self-interested actions
The power of a central bank

questions.question: What was the name of the first artificial satellite launched into Earth's orbit, by the Soviet Union in 1957?
Which of the noble gases is the most reactive and able to form stable chemical compounds?
The Krebs cycle (or Citric Acid Cycle) primarily occurs in which part of the eukaryotic cell?
The 'Scramble for Africa' was largely initiated by which 1884-1885 international meeting in Europe?
What is the opening line of Leo Tolstoy's 'Anna Karenina'?
options: 'Happy families are all alike; every unhappy family is unhappy in its own way.'
'It was the best of times, it was the worst of times...'

questions.question: In music, what does the term 'crescendo' instruct a musician to do?
The Atacama Desert, one of the driest places on Earth, is located primarily in which South American country?
What does 'SQL' stand for in the context of databases?
Which philosopher wrote 'Thus Spoke Zarathustra' and is known for the concept of the 'Übermensch' (Overman)?
What is the name of the international organization that works to secure global financial stability and promote international trade, created at Bretton Woods?
The discovery of the double helix structure of DNA, published in 1953, is primarily credited to which two scientists?
What type of radioactive decay involves the emission of an electron or a positron from an atomic nucleus?
The Cushing's triad, a physiological response to increased intracranial pressure, consists of bradycardia, irregular respiration, and what else?
What ancient city, a rival to Rome, was famously destroyed at the end of the Third Punic War with the phrase 'Carthago delenda est'?
In Homer's 'Odyssey,' what is the name of Odysseus's son, who searches for his father?
Which composer's Symphony No. 9, also known as the 'Choral' symphony, includes the famous 'Ode to Joy'?
What is the term for a point on the Earth's surface directly above the hypocenter or focus of an earthquake?
The term 'API' in software development stands for what?
In Egyptian mythology, who is the god of the afterlife, death, and resurrection?
In political science, what form of government is characterized by the rule of a small group of people?
Which band released the influential 1977 punk rock album 'Never Mind the Bollocks, Here's the...'?
What is the name for a particle that is its own antiparticle?
Which vitamin is essential for blood coagulation, and its deficiency can lead to bleeding disorders?
The character 'Big Brother' and the concept of 'thoughtcrime' are from which dystopian novel?
What is the name of the minimalist sculpture by Auguste Rodin depicting a solitary, pensive figure?
Which country has the most international land borders?
What does the 'S' in 'HTTPS' stand for?
Existentialism is a school of philosophy most associated with which 20th-century French thinker?
What does 'GDP' stand for in economics?
The Turing Test, developed by Alan Turing, is a test of a machine's ability to exhibit what?
options: Intelligent behavior indistinguishable from a human's
